text: CHAPTER FOUR
author: Virginia Woolf

text: What's the use of trying to read Shakespeare, especially in one of those
author: Virginia Woolf

text: little thin paper editions whose pages get ruffled, or stuck together
author: Virginia Woolf

text: with sea-water? Although the plays of Shakespeare had frequently been
author: Virginia Woolf

text: praised, even quoted, and placed higher than the Greek, never since they
author: Virginia Woolf

text: started had Jacob managed to read one through. Yet what an opportunity!
author: Virginia Woolf

text: For the Scilly Isles had been sighted by Timmy Durrant lying like
author: Virginia Woolf

text: mountain-tops almost a-wash in precisely the right place. His
author: Virginia Woolf

text: calculations had worked perfectly, and really the sight of him sitting
author: Virginia Woolf

text: there, with his hand on the tiller, rosy gilled, with a sprout of beard,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: looking sternly at the stars, then at a compass, spelling out quite
author: Virginia Woolf

text: correctly his page of the eternal lesson-book, would have moved a woman.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Jacob, of course, was not a woman. The sight of Timmy Durrant was no
author: Virginia Woolf

text: sight for him, nothing to set against the sky and worship; far from it.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: They had quarrelled. Why the right way to open a tin of beef, with
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Shakespeare on board, under conditions of such splendour, should have
author: Virginia Woolf

text: turned them to sulky schoolboys, none can tell. Tinned beef is cold
author: Virginia Woolf

text: eating, though; and salt water spoils biscuits; and the waves tumble and
author: Virginia Woolf

text: lollop much the same hour after hour--tumble and lollop all across the
author: Virginia Woolf

text: horizon. Now a spray of seaweed floats past-now a log of wood. Ships
author: Virginia Woolf

text: have been wrecked here. One or two go past, keeping their own side of
author: Virginia Woolf

text: the road. Timmy knew where they were bound, what their cargoes were,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: and, by looking through his glass, could tell the name of the line, and
author: Virginia Woolf

text: even guess what dividends it paid its shareholders. Yet that was no
author: Virginia Woolf

text: reason for Jacob to turn sulky.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: The Scilly Isles had the look of mountain-tops almost a-wash....
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: across.

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: on them; and, somehow or other, loveliness is infernally sad. Yes, the
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: breaking unseen by any one make one remember the overpowering sorrow.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: And what can this sorrow be?
author: Virginia Woolf

text: It is brewed by the earth itself. It comes from the houses on the coast.

author: Virginia Woolf

text: pane of glass. To escape is vain.

text: fall upon the tea-table, fade upon the passage, making appointments,

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: Well, people have tried. Byron wrote letters. So did Cowper. For
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: turned from the sheet that endures to the sheet that perishes, pushing
author: Virginia Woolf

text: aside the tea-tray, drawing close to the fire (for letters are written
author: Virginia Woolf

text: when the dark presses round a bright red cave), and addressed themselves
author: Virginia Woolf

text: to the task of reaching, touching, penetrating the individual heart.
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: leaf.

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: the English language fails to provide; Jacob had written in his day long
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: clogged with mud, it rolls across a page. Her spelling was abominable.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Her sentiments infantile. And for some reason when she wrote she
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: the hand itself rambling and redeemed only by the fact--which always did
author: Virginia Woolf

text: redeem Florinda--by the fact that she cared. Yes, whether it was for
author: Virginia Woolf

text: chocolate creams, hot baths, the shape of her face in the looking-glass,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Florinda could no more pretend a feeling than swallow whisky.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Incontinent was her rejection. Great men are truthful, and these little
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: "Life is wicked--life is detestable," cried Rose Shaw.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: The strange thing about life is that though the nature of it must have
author: Virginia Woolf

text: been apparent to every one for hundreds of years, no one has left any
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: corner?
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: you going if instead of brushing past the old man with the white beard,
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: continuity of our ways. Yet we keep straight on.

text: Rose Shaw, talking in rather an emotional manner to Mr. Bowley at Mrs.
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: because a man called Jimmy refused to marry a woman called (if memory
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: Both were beautiful. Both were inanimate. The oval tea-table invariably
author: Virginia Woolf

text: separated them, and the plate of biscuits was all he ever gave her. He
author: Virginia Woolf

text: bowed; she inclined her head. They danced. He danced divinely. They sat
author: Virginia Woolf

text: in the alcove; never a word was said. Her pillow was wet with tears.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Kind Mr. Bowley and dear Rose Shaw marvelled and deplored. Bowley had
author: Virginia Woolf

text: rooms in the Albany. Rose was re-born every evening precisely as the
author: Virginia Woolf

text: clock struck eight. All four were civilization's triumphs, and if you
author: Virginia Woolf

text: persist that a command of the English language is part of our
author: Virginia Woolf

text: inheritance, one can only reply that beauty is almost always dumb. Male
author: Virginia Woolf

text: beauty in association with female beauty breeds in the onlooker a sense
author: Virginia Woolf

text: of fear. Often have I seen them--Helen and Jimmy--and likened them to
author: Virginia Woolf

text: ships adrift, and feared for my own little craft. Or again, have you
author: Virginia Woolf

text: ever watched fine collie dogs couchant at twenty yards' distance? As she
author: Virginia Woolf

text: passed him his cup there was that quiver in her flanks. Bowley saw what
author: Virginia Woolf

text: was up-asked Jimmy to breakfast. Helen must have confided in Rose. For
author: Virginia Woolf

text: my own part, I find it exceedingly difficult to interpret songs without
author: Virginia Woolf

text: words. And now Jimmy feeds crows in Flanders and Helen visits hospitals.

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: volubly from dark eyes, loose lips, as he fingers the meat silently, his
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: him. These events are features of our landscape. A foreigner coming to
author: Virginia Woolf

text: London could scarcely miss seeing St. Paul's.) He judged life. These
author: Virginia Woolf

text: pinkish and greenish newspapers are thin sheets of gelatine pressed
author: Virginia Woolf

text: nightly over the brain and heart of the world. They take the impression
author: Virginia Woolf

text: of the whole. Jacob cast his eye over it. A strike, a murder, football,
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: CHAPTER NINE
author: Virginia Woolf

text: The Countess of Rocksbier sat at the head of the table alone with Jacob.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Fed upon champagne and spices for at least two centuries (four, if you
author: Virginia Woolf

text: count the female line), the Countess Lucy looked well fed. A
author: Virginia Woolf

text: discriminating nose she had for scents, prolonged, as if in quest of
author: Virginia Woolf

text: them; her underlip protruded a narrow red shelf; her eyes were small,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: with sandy tufts for eyebrows, and her jowl was heavy. Behind her (the
author: Virginia Woolf

text: window looked on Grosvenor Square) stood Moll Pratt on the pavement,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: offering violets for sale; and Mrs. Hilda Thomas, lifting her skirts,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: preparing to cross the road. One was from Walworth; the other from
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Putney. Both wore black stockings, but Mrs. Thomas was coiled in furs.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: The comparison was much in Lady Rocksbier's favour. Moll had more
author: Virginia Woolf

text: humour, but was violent; stupid too. Hilda Thomas was mealy-mouthed, all
author: Virginia Woolf

text: her silver frames aslant; egg-cups in the drawing-room; and the windows
author: Virginia Woolf

text: shrouded. Lady Rocksbier, whatever the deficiencies of her profile, had
author: Virginia Woolf

text: been a great rider to hounds. She used her knife with authority, tore
author: Virginia Woolf

text: her chicken bones, asking Jacob's pardon, with her own hands.
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: CHAPTER TEN
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Through the disused graveyard in the parish of St. Pancras, Fanny Elmer
author: Virginia Woolf

text: strayed between the white tombs which lean against the wall, crossing
author: Virginia Woolf

text: the grass to read a name, hurrying on when the grave-keeper approached,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: hurrying into the street, pausing now by a window with blue china, now
author: Virginia Woolf

text: quickly making up for lost time, abruptly entering a baker's shop,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: buying rolls, adding cakes, going on again so that any one wishing to
author: Virginia Woolf

text: follow must fairly trot. She was not drably shabby, though. She wore
author: Virginia Woolf

text: silk stockings, and silver-buckled shoes, only the red feather in her
author: Virginia Woolf

text: hat drooped, and the clasp of her bag was weak, for out fell a copy of
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Madame Tussaud's programme as she walked. She had the ankles of a stag.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Her face was hidden. Of course, in this dusk, rapid movements, quick
author: Virginia Woolf

text: glances, and soaring hopes come naturally enough. She passed right
author: Virginia Woolf

text: beneath Jacob's window.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: The house was flat, dark, and silent. Jacob was at home engaged upon a
author: Virginia Woolf

text: chess problem, the board being on a stool between his knees. One hand
author: Virginia Woolf

text: was fingering the hair at the back of his head. He slowly brought it
author: Virginia Woolf

text: forward and raised the white queen from her square; then put her down
author: Virginia Woolf

text: again on the same spot. He filled his pipe; ruminated; moved two pawns;
author: Virginia Woolf

text: advanced the white knight; then ruminated with one finger upon the
author: Virginia Woolf

text: bishop. Now Fanny Elmer passed beneath the window.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: She was on her way to sit to Nick Bramham the painter.
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: and greasy, and the cassocks in place, and the hymn-books on the ledges.

text: It is a ship with all its crew aboard. The timbers strain to hold the
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: CHAPTER TWELVE
author: Virginia Woolf

text: The water fell off a ledge like lead--like a chain with thick white
author: Virginia Woolf

text: links. The train ran out into a steep green meadow, and Jacob saw
author: Virginia Woolf

text: striped tulips growing and heard a bird singing, in Italy.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: A motor car full of Italian officers ran along the flat road and kept up
author: Virginia Woolf

text: with the train, raising dust behind it. There were trees laced together
author: Virginia Woolf

text: with vines--as Virgil said. Here was a station; and a tremendous
author: Virginia Woolf

text: leave-taking going on, with women in high yellow boots and odd pale boys
author: Virginia Woolf

text: in ringed socks. Virgil's bees had gone about the plains of Lombardy. It
author: Virginia Woolf

text: was the custom of the ancients to train vines between elms. Then at
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Milan there were sharp-winged hawks, of a bright brown, cutting figures
author: Virginia Woolf

text: over the roofs.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: These Italian carriages get damnably hot with the afternoon sun on them,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: and the chances are that before the engine has pulled to the top of the
author: Virginia Woolf

text: gorge the clanking chain will have broken. Up, up, up, it goes, like a
author: Virginia Woolf

text: train on a scenic railway. Every peak is covered with sharp trees, and
author: Virginia Woolf

text: amazing white villages are crowded on ledges. There is always a white
author: Virginia Woolf

text: tower on the very summit, flat red-frilled roofs, and a sheer drop
author: Virginia Woolf

text: beneath. It is not a country in which one walks after tea. For one thing
author: Virginia Woolf

text: there is no grass. A whole hillside will be ruled with olive trees.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Already in April the earth is clotted into dry dust between them. And
author: Virginia Woolf

text: there are neither stiles nor footpaths, nor lanes chequered with the
author: Virginia Woolf

text: shadows of leaves nor eighteenth-century inns with bow-windows, where
author: Virginia Woolf

text: one eats ham and eggs. Oh no, Italy is all fierceness, bareness,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: exposure, and black priests shuffling along the roads. It is strange,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: too, how you never get away from villas.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Still, to be travelling on one's own with a hundred pounds to spend is a
author: Virginia Woolf

text: fine affair. And if his money gave out, as it probably would, he would
author: Virginia Woolf

text: go on foot. He could live on bread and wine--the wine in straw
author: Virginia Woolf

text: bottles--for after doing Greece he was going to knock off Rome. The
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Roman civilization was a very inferior affair, no doubt. But Bonamy
author: Virginia Woolf

text: talked a lot of rot, all the same. "You ought to have been in Athens,"
author: Virginia Woolf

text: he would say to Bonamy when he got back. "Standing on the Parthenon," he
author: Virginia Woolf

text: would say, or "The ruins of the Coliseum suggest some fairly sublime
author: Virginia Woolf

text: reflections," which he would write out at length in letters. It might
author: Virginia Woolf

text: turn to an essay upon civilization. A comparison between the ancients
author: Virginia Woolf

text: and moderns, with some pretty sharp hits at Mr. Asquith--something in
author: Virginia Woolf

text: the style of Gibbon.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: A stout gentleman laboriously hauled himself in, dusty, baggy, slung
author: Virginia Woolf

text: with gold chains, and Jacob, regretting that he did not come of the
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Latin race, looked out of the window.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: It is a strange reflection that by travelling two days and nights you
author: Virginia Woolf

text: are in the heart of Italy. Accidental villas among olive trees appear;
author: Virginia Woolf

text: and men-servants watering the cactuses. Black victorias drive in between
author: Virginia Woolf

text: pompous pillars with plaster shields stuck to them. It is at once
author: Virginia Woolf

text: momentary and astonishingly intimate--to be displayed before the eyes of
author: Virginia Woolf

text: a foreigner. And there is a lonely hill-top where no one ever comes, and
author: Virginia Woolf

text: yet it is seen by me who was lately driving down Piccadilly on an
author: Virginia Woolf

text: omnibus. And what I should like would be to get out among the fields,
author: Virginia Woolf

text: sit down and hear the grasshoppers, and take up a handful of
author: Virginia Woolf

text: earth--Italian earth, as this is Italian dust upon my shoes.
author: Virginia Woolf

text: Jacob heard them crying strange names at railway stations through the
author: Virginia Woolf

text: night. The train stopped and he heard frogs croaking close by, and he
author: Virginia Woolf

text: wrinkled back the blind cautiously and saw a vast strange marsh all
author: Virginia Woolf

text: white in the moonlight. The carriage was thick with cigar smoke, which
author: Virginia Woolf

text: floated round the globe with the green shade on it. The Italian
author: Virginia Woolf

text: gentleman lay snoring with his boots off and his waistcoat unbuttoned....
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: intolerable weariness--sitting in hotels by oneself and looking at
author: Virginia Woolf

text: monuments--he'd have done better to go to Cornwall with Timmy Durrant....
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

text: him and the light showed through, but the man was reaching across him to
author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf

author: Virginia Woolf
